title: INFLUENCE OF DRUG-POLYMER INTERACTIONS ON RELEASE KINETICS OF PLGA AND PLA/PEG NPS

authors.name: Merve Gul
affiliations: Department of Drug Sciences, University of Pavia
Department of Chemical Engineering, Universitat Politècnica de Catalunya (UPC-EEBE)

authors.name: Ida Genta
affiliations: Department of Drug Sciences, University of Pavia

authors.name: Maria M. Perez Madrigal
affiliations: Department of Chemical Engineering, Universitat Politècnica de Catalunya (UPC-EEBE)

authors.name: Carlos Aleman
affiliations: Department of Chemical Engineering, Universitat Politècnica de Catalunya (UPC-EEBE)
Barcelona Research Center for Multiscale Science and Engineering, EEBE, Universitat Politècnica de Catalunya

authors.name: Enrica Chiesa
affiliations: Department of Drug Sciences, University of Pavia

summary: The study investigates the influence of drug-polymer interactions on the release kinetics of PLGA and PLA/PEG nanoparticles (NPs) for controlled drug delivery. Key findings highlight that CURC-loaded PLGA NPs exhibit slower release rates and higher encapsulation efficiency, making them suitable for controlled delivery in regenerative medicine.
methods: Microfluidic-based synthesis was used to prepare nano-sized carriers (PLGA NPs and PLA/PEG micelles) for drug delivery. The study involved physical characterization of NPs, drug loading, release kinetics analysis, and cytotoxicity assessment.
results: NPs had uniform size distribution with PDI ≤0.2. PLGA NPs showed a diameter (Dₕ) of 61.91 ± 1.86 nm, zeta potential (ζ) of 13.74 ± 0.97 mV, and encapsulation efficiency (EE%) of 2.81 ± 0.81 µg/mg. CURC-loaded PLGA NPs exhibited slower release rates and higher encapsulation efficiency compared to PLA/PEG micelles. No or slight cytotoxic effects were observed on NHDFs.
